1.rationale:
I'll think through the situation:

My snake (#1) is at (6,1) on a 10×10 board. The apples are at (1,1), (5,5), (2,6), (3,4), and (2,7), while enemy snake (#2) is at (4,3).

Looking at distances, the apple at (5,5) is promising—it’s 1 unit left and 4 units up from (6,1), for a total Manhattan distance of 5. The apple at (1,1) is 5 units to the left, which is equally distant but on a single axis. Starting from (6,1), I want to approach one of these apples without colliding with a wall or the enemy snake.

From (6,1), I have these safe immediate moves:
• UP to (6,2)
• LEFT to (5,1)
• RIGHT to (7,1)
• DOWN to (6,0)

Moving RIGHT takes me farther from the primary targets, and DOWN isn’t moving closer to any apple. Both UP and LEFT reduce the distance to the apple at (5,5), but moving LEFT (to (5,1)) immediately puts me in line horizontally with that apple. I can then plan to move upwards toward (5,5) while avoiding the enemy snake at (4,3).

Thus, I’ll move LEFT. 

Next move: LEFT.

My snake (#1) is at (6,1) on a 10×10 board. The apples are at (1,1), (5,5), (2,6), (3,4), and (2,7), while enemy snake (#2) is at (4,3).

Looking at distances, the apple at (5,5) is promising—it’s 1 unit left and 4 units up from (6,1), for a total Manhattan distance of 5. The apple at (1,1) is 5 units to the left, which is equally distant but on a single axis. Starting from (6,1), I want to approach one of these apples without colliding with a wall or the enemy snake.

From (6,1), I have these safe immediate moves:
• UP to (6,2)
• LEFT to (5,1)
• RIGHT to (7,1)
• DOWN to (6,0)

Moving RIGHT takes me farther from the primary targets, and DOWN isn’t moving closer to any apple. Both UP and LEFT reduce the distance to the apple at (5,5), but moving LEFT (to (5,1)) immediately puts me in line horizontally with that apple. I can then plan to move upwards toward (5,5) while avoiding the enemy snake at (4,3).

Thus, I’ll move LEFT. 

Next move: LEFT.

Looking at the board, I see that there are apples at (1,1), (5,5), (2,6), (3,4), and (2,7). The closest apple to me is at (3,4), which is just one square away to my right. I should aim for that apple first since it's the closest and will help me grow and gain a point. I need to be cautious of the enemy snake #1 at (6,1), but it's far enough that it shouldn't be an immediate concern. My strategy for the next turn is to continue focusing on the closest apples while keeping an eye on the enemy snake's movements.

• RIGHT to (6,1): too far from any apple.

• LEFT to (4,1): safe and puts me on track for the apple at (1,1).

Thus, to secure a guaranteed safe apple without risking an encounter with the enemy, I’ll move LEFT.
